Tensions over rising Polish nationalism and the economic effects of the Continental System led to renewed confrontation with Russia. To enforce his blockade, Napoleon launched an invasion of Russia in the summer of 1812. The resulting campaign witnessed the catastrophic collapse of the Grand Army, forcing the French to retreat, as well as leading to the widespread destruction of Russian lands and cities. In 1813, Prussia and Austria joined Russian forces in a Sixth Coalition against France. A chaotic military campaign in Central Europe eventually culminated in a large Allied army defeating Napoleon at the Battle of Leipzig in October. The next year, the Allies invaded France and captured Paris, forcing Napoleon to abdicate in April 1814. He was exiled to the island of Elba. The Bourbons were restored to power and the French lost most of the territories that they had conquered since the Revolution. However, Napoleon escaped from Elba in February 1815 and took control of the government once again. The Allies responded by forming

In the Hesiodic Catalogue of Women, Graecus is presented as the son of Zeus and Pandora II, sister of Hellen the patriarch of Hellenes. Hellen was the son of Deucalion who ruled around Phthia in central Greece. The Parian Chronicle mentions that when Deucalion became king of Phthia, the previously called Graikoi were named Hellenes. Aristotle notes that the Hellenes were related with Grai/Greeks (Meteorologica I.xiv) a native name of a Dorian tribe in Epirus which was used by the Illyrians. He also claims that the great deluge must have occurred in the region around Dodona, where the Selloi dwelt. However, according to the Greek tradition it is more possible that the homeland of the Greeks was originally in central Greece. A modern theory derives the name Greek (Latin Graeci) from Graikos, "inhabitant of Graia/Graea," a town on the coast of Boeotia. Greek colonists from Graia helped to found Cumae (900 BC) in Italy,

In biology, energy is an attribute of all biological systems from the biosphere to the smallest living organism. Within an organism it is responsible for growth and development of a biological cell or an organelle of a biological organism. Energy is thus often said to be stored by cells in the structures of molecules of substances such as carbohydrates (including sugars), lipids, and proteins, which release energy when reacted with oxygen in respiration. In human terms, the human equivalent (H-e) (Human energy conversion) indicates, for a given amount of energy expenditure, the relative quantity of energy needed for human metabolism, assuming an average human energy expenditure of 12,500 kJ per day and a basal metabolic rate of 80 watts. For example, if our bodies run (on average) at 80 watts, then a light bulb running at 100 watts is running at 1.25 human equivalents (100 ÷ 80) i.e. 1.25 H-e. From 1877 to 1878, the area suffered a rash of stagecoach robberies. Most notable, however, were the two holdups committed by masked road-agent William Whitney Brazelton. Brazelton held up two stages in the summer of 1878 near Point of Mountain Station approximately 17 mi (27 km) northwest of Tucson. John Clum, of Tombstone, Arizona fame was one of the passengers. Brazelton was eventually tracked down and killed on Monday August 19, 1878, in a mesquite bosque along the Santa Cruz River 3 miles (5 km) south of Tucson by Pima County Sheriff Charles A. Shibell and his citizen's posse. Brazelton had been suspected of highway robbery not only in the Tucson area, but also in the Prescott region and Silver City, New Mexico area as well. Brazelton's crimes prompted John J. Valentine, Sr. of Wells, Fargo & Co. to send special agent and future Pima County sheriff Bob Paul to investigate. In 633 AD, Rashidun Arabs invaded Iran and conquered it by 651 AD, largely converting Iranian people from their indigenous faiths of Manichaeism and Zoroastrianism to Sunni Islam. Arabic replaced Persian as the official language, while Persian remained the language of both ordinary people and of literature. Iran became a major contributor to the Islamic Golden Age, producing many influential scientists, scholars, artists, and thinkers. Establishment of the Safavid Dynasty in 1501, converted the Iranian people from Sunni Islam to Twelver Shia Islam, and made Twelver Shia Islam the official religion of Iran. Safavid conversion of Iran from Sunnism to Shiism marked one of the most important turning points in Iranian and Muslim history. Carolingian art was produced for a small group of figures around the court, and the monasteries and churches they supported. It was dominated by efforts to regain the dignity and classicism of imperial Roman and Byzantine art, but was also influenced by the Insular art of the British Isles. Insular art integrated the energy of Irish Celtic and Anglo-Saxon Germanic styles of ornament with Mediterranean forms such as the book, and established many characteristics of art for the rest of the medieval period. Surviving religious works from the Early Middle Ages are mostly illuminated manuscripts and carved ivories, originally made for metalwork that has since been melted down. Objects in precious metals were the most prestigious form of art, but almost all are lost except for a few crosses such as the Cross of Lothair, several reliquaries, and finds such as the Anglo-Saxon burial at Sutton Hoo and the hoards of Gourdon from Merovingian France, Guarrazar from

The brief peace in Europe allowed Napoleon to focus on the French colonies abroad. Saint-Domingue had managed to acquire a high level of political autonomy during the Revolutionary Wars, with Toussaint Louverture installing himself as de facto dictator by 1801. Napoleon saw his chance to recuperate the formerly wealthy colony when he signed the Treaty of Amiens. During the Revolution, the National Convention voted to abolish slavery in February 1794. Under the terms of Amiens, however, Napoleon agreed to appease British demands by not abolishing slavery in any colonies where the 1794 decree had never been implemented. The resulting Law of 20 May never applied to colonies like Guadeloupe or Guyane, even though rogue generals and other officials used the pretext of peace as an opportunity to reinstate slavery in some of these places. The Law of 20 May officially restored the slave trade to the Caribbean colonies, not slavery itself. The works of Virgil almost from the moment of their publication revolutionized Latin poetry. The Eclogues, Georgics, and above all the Aeneid became standard texts in school curricula with which all educated Romans were familiar. Poets following Virgil often refer intertextually to his works to generate meaning in their own poetry. The Augustan poet Ovid parodies the opening lines of the Aeneid in Amores 1.1.1–2, and his summary of the Aeneas story in Book 14 of the Metamorphoses, the so-called "mini-Aeneid", has been viewed as a particularly important example of post-Virgilian response to the epic genre. Lucan's epic, the Bellum Civile has been considered an anti-Virgilian epic, disposing with the divine mechanism, treating historical events, and diverging drastically from Virgilian epic practice. By the early 18th century, the Maratha Kingdom had transformed itself into the Maratha Empire under the rule of the Peshwas (prime ministers). In 1737, the Marathas defeated a Mughal army in their capital, Delhi itself in Battle of Delhi (1737). The Marathas continued their military campaigns against Mughals, Nizam, Nawab of Bengal and Durrani Empire to further extend their boundaries. Gordon explained how the Maratha systematically took control over new regions. They would start with annual raids, followed by collecting ransom from villages and towns while the declining Mughal Empire retained nominal control and finally taking over the region. He explained it with the example of Malwa region. Marathas built an efficient system of public administration known for its attention to detail. It succeeded in raising revenue in districts that recovered from years of raids, up to levels previously enjoyed by the Mughals. Throughout the history of the South Slavs, the vernacular, literary, and written languages (e.g. Chakavian, Kajkavian, Shtokavian) of the various regions and ethnicities developed and diverged independently. Prior to the 19th century, they were collectively called "Illyric", "Slavic", "Slavonian", "Bosnian", "Dalmatian", "Serbian" or "Croatian". As such, the term Serbo-Croatian was first used by Jacob Grimm in 1824, popularized by the Vienna philologist Jernej Kopitar in the following decades, and accepted by Croatian Zagreb grammarians in 1854 and 1859. At that time, Serb and Croat lands were still part of the Ottoman and Austrian Empires. Officially, the language was called variously Serbo-Croat, Croato-Serbian, Serbian and Croatian, Croatian and Serbian, Serbian or Croatian, Croatian or Serbian. By 1959, American observers believed that the Soviet Union would be the first to get a human into space, because of the time needed to prepare for Mercury's first launch. On April 12, 1961, the USSR surprised the world again by launching Yuri Gagarin into a single orbit around the Earth in a craft they called Vostok 1. They dubbed Gagarin the first cosmonaut, roughly translated from Russian and Greek as "sailor of the universe". Although he had the ability to take over manual control of his spacecraft in an emergency by opening an envelope he had in the cabin that contained a code that could be typed into the computer, it was flown in an automatic mode as a precaution; medical science at that time did not know what would happen to a human in the weightlessness of space. The island of Saint Helena has a total area of 122 km2 (47 sq mi), and is composed largely of rugged terrain of volcanic origin (the last volcanic eruptions occurred about 7 million years ago). Coastal areas are covered in volcanic rock and warmer and drier than the centre. The highest point of the island is Diana's Peak at 818 m (2,684 ft). In 1996 it became the island's first national park. Much of the island is covered by New Zealand flax, a legacy of former industry, but there are some original trees augmented by plantations, including those of the Millennium Forest project which was established in 2002 to replant part of the lost Great Wood and is now managed by the Saint Helena National Trust. In January 1938, Milt Gabler started recording for his new label, Commodore Records, and to allow for longer continuous performances, he recorded some 12-inch records. Eddie Condon explained: "Gabler realized that a jam session needs room for development." The first two 12-inch recordings did not take advantage of the extra length: "Carnegie Drag" was 3:15; "Carnegie Jump", 2:41. But at the second session, on April 30, the two 12-inch recordings were longer: "Embraceable You" was 4:05; "Serenade to a Shylock", 4:32. Another way around the time limitation was to issue a selection on both sides of a single record. Vaudeville stars Gallagher and Shean recorded "Mr. Gallagher and Mr. Shean", written by Irving and Jack Kaufman, as two sides of a 10-inch 78 in 1922 for Cameo. However, asymmetry of causation can be observed in a non-arbitrary way which is not metaphysical in the case of a human hand dropping a cup of water which smashes into fragments on a hard floor, spilling the liquid. In this order, the causes of the resultant pattern of cup fragments and water spill is easily attributable in terms of the trajectory of the cup, irregularities in its structure, angle of its impact on the floor, etc. However, applying the same event in reverse, it is difficult to explain why the various pieces of the cup should fly up into the human hand and reassemble precisely into the shape of a cup, or why the water should position itself entirely within the cup. The causes of the resultant structure and shape of the cup and the encapsulation of the water by the hand within the cup are not easily attributable, as neither hand nor floor can achieve such formations of the cup or water. The state seemed at relative calm compared to the rest of the country due to its close ties to the United States until 1841. In 1843 the possibility of war was anticipated by the state government and it began to reinforce the defense lines along the political boundary with Texas. Supplies of weapons were sent to fully equip the military and took steps to improve efficiency at the presidios. Later, the Regimen for the Defenders of the Border were organized by the state which were made up of: light cavalry, four squads of two brigades, and a small force of 14 men and 42 officials at the price of 160,603 pesos per year. During the beginning of the 1840s, private citizens took it upon themselves to stop the commercial caravans of supplies from the United States, but being so far away from the large suppliers in central Mexico the caravan was allowed to continue in March 1844.

John treated the interdict as "the equivalent of a papal declaration of war". He responded by attempting to punish Innocent personally and to drive a wedge between those English clergy that might support him and those allying themselves firmly with the authorities in Rome. John seized the lands of those clergy unwilling to conduct services, as well as those estates linked to Innocent himself; he arrested the illicit concubines that many clerics kept during the period, only releasing them after the payment of fines; he seized the lands of members of the church who had fled England, and he promised protection for those clergy willing to remain loyal to him. In many cases, individual institutions were able to negotiate terms for managing their own properties and keeping the produce of their estates. By 1209 the situation showed no signs of resolution, and Innocent threatened to excommunicate John if he did not acquiesce to Langton's appointment. The Canadian football field is 150 yards (137 m) long and 65 yards (59 m) wide with end zones 20 yards (18 m) deep, and goal lines 110 yards (101 m) apart. At each goal line is a set of 40-foot-high (12 m) goalposts, which consist of two uprights joined by an 18 1⁄2-foot-long (5.6 m) crossbar which is 10 feet (3 m) above the goal line. The goalposts may be H-shaped (both posts fixed in the ground) although in the higher-calibre competitions the tuning-fork design (supported by a single curved post behind the goal line, so that each post starts 10 feet (3 m) above the ground) is preferred. In 1939, the Bureau began compiling a custodial detention list with the names of those who would be taken into custody in the event of war with Axis nations. The majority of the names on the list belonged to Issei community leaders, as the FBI investigation built on an existing Naval Intelligence index that had focused on Japanese Americans in Hawaii and the West Coast, but many German and Italian nationals also found their way onto the secret list. Robert Shivers, head of the Honolulu office, obtained permission from Hoover to start detaining those on the list on December 7, 1941, while bombs were still falling over Pearl Harbor. Mass arrests and searches of homes (in most cases conducted without warrants) began a few hours after the attack, and over the next several weeks more than 5,500 Issei men were taken into FBI custody. South Korea: The event was held in Seoul, which hosted the 1988 Summer Olympics, on April 27. Intended torchbearers Choi Seung-kook and Park Won-sun boycotted the event to protest against the Chinese government's crackdown in Tibet. More than 8,000 riot police were deployed to guard the 24-kilometre route, which began at Olympic Park, which was built when Seoul hosted the 1988 Summer Games. On the day of the torch relay in Seoul, Chinese students clashed with protesters, throwing rocks, bottles, and punches. A North Korean defector whose brother defected to China but was captured and executed by the DPRK, attempted to set himself on fire in protest of China's treatment of North Korean refugees. The deliberate or accidental hybridising of two or more species of closely related animals through captive breeding is a human activity which has been in existence for millennia and has grown in recent times for economic purposes. The number of successful interspecific mammalian hybrids is relatively small, although it has come to be known that there is a significant number of naturally occurring hybrids between forms or regional varieties of a single species.[citation needed] These may form zones of gradation known as clines. Indeed, the distinction between some hitherto distinct species can become clouded once it can be shown that they may not only breed but produce fertile offspring. Some hybrid animals exhibit greater strength and resilience than either parent. This is known as hybrid vigor. The existence of the mule (donkey sire; horse dam) being used widely as a hardy draught animal throughout ancient and modern history is testament to this. A number of novel ideas about religion developed with the Enlightenment, including Deism and talk of atheism. Deism, according to Thomas Paine, is the simple belief in God the Creator, with no reference to the Bible or any other miraculous source. Instead, the Deist relies solely on personal reason to guide his creed, which was eminently agreeable to many thinkers of the time. Atheism was much discussed, but there were few proponents. Wilson and Reill note that, "In fact, very few enlightened intellectuals, even when they were vocal critics of Christianity, were true atheists. Rather, they were critics of orthodox belief, wedded rather to skepticism, deism, vitalism, or perhaps pantheism." Some followed Pierre Bayle and argued that atheists could indeed be moral men. BYU has 21 NCAA varsity teams. Nineteen of these teams played mainly in the Mountain West Conference from its inception in 1999 until the school left that conference in 2011. Prior to that time BYU teams competed in the Western Athletic Conference. All teams are named the "Cougars", and Cosmo the Cougar has been the school's mascot since 1953. The school's fight song is the Cougar Fight Song. Because many of its players serve on full-time missions for two years (men when they're 18, women when 19), BYU athletes are often older on average than other schools' players. The NCAA allows students to serve missions for two years without subtracting that time from their eligibility period. Of major Canadian cities, St. John's is the foggiest (124 days), windiest (24.3 km/h (15.1 mph) average speed), and cloudiest (1,497 hours of sunshine). St. John's experiences milder temperatures during the winter season in comparison to other Canadian cities, and has the mildest winter for any Canadian city outside of British Columbia. Precipitation is frequent and often heavy, falling year round. On average, summer is the driest season, with only occasional thunderstorm activity, and the wettest months are from October to January, with December the wettest single month, with nearly 165 millimetres of precipitation on average. The success of its football team made Notre Dame a household name. The success of Note Dame reflected rising status of Irish Americans and Catholics in the 1920s. Catholics rallied up around the team and listen to the games on the radio, especially when it knocked off the schools that symbolized the Protestant establishment in America — Harvard, Yale, Princeton, and Army. Yet this role as high-profile flagship institution of Catholicism made it an easy target of anti-Catholicism. The most remarkable episode of violence was the clash between Notre Dame students and the Ku Klux Klan in 1924. Nativism and anti-Catholicism, especially when directed towards immigrants, were cornerstones of the KKK's rhetoric, and Notre Dame was seen as a symbol of the threat posed by the Catholic Church. Switzerland lies between latitudes 45° and 48° N, and longitudes 5° and 11° E. It contains three basic topographical areas: the Swiss Alps to the south, the Swiss Plateau or Central Plateau, and the Jura mountains on the west. The Alps are a high mountain range running across the central-south of the country, comprising about 60% of the country's total area. The majority of the Swiss population live in the Swiss Plateau. Among the high valleys of the Swiss Alps many glaciers are found, totalling an area of 1,063 square kilometres (410 sq mi). From these originate the headwaters of several major rivers, such as the Rhine, Inn, Ticino and Rhône, which flow in the four cardinal directions into the whole of Europe. Boston has a continental climate with some maritime influence, and using the −3 °C (27 °F) coldest month (January) isotherm, the city lies within the transition zone from a humid subtropical climate (Köppen Cfa) to a humid continental climate (Köppen Dfa), although the suburbs north and west of the city are significantly colder in winter and solidly fall under the latter categorization; the city lies at the transition between USDA plant hardiness zones 6b (most of the city) and 7a (Downtown, South Boston, and East Boston neighborhoods). Summers are typically warm to hot, rainy, and humid, while winters oscillate between periods of cold rain and snow, with cold temperatures. Spring and fall are usually mild, with varying conditions dependent on wind direction and jet stream positioning. As Muslim institutions of higher learning, the madrasa had the legal designation of waqf. In central and eastern Islamic lands, the view that the madrasa, as a charitable endowment, will remain under the control of the donor (and their descendent), resulted in a "spurt" of establishment of madaris in the 11th and 12th centuries. However, in Western Islamic lands, where the Maliki views prohibited donors from controlling their endowment, madaris were not as popular. Unlike the corporate designation of Western institutions of higher learning, the waqf designation seemed to have led to the exclusion of non-orthodox religious subjects such a philosophy and natural science from the curricula. Mammalian hair , also known as pelage , can vary in color between populations , organisms within a population , and even on the individual organism . Light-dark color variation may arise by a combination of allelic mutations in pigmentation genes , as well as by gene conversion ( cross hybridization of two different types of genes ) . Cross hybridization of genes from different populations leads to pigmentation variants not seen in either population , and to different proportions , in which a single gene can express two different phenotypic traits , depending on which allele it is . In this work , we use population genetics techniques such as allelic linkage disequilibrium , genotyping techniques based on hapl otyping , and genetic distance analysis , to quantify variation in pelage color in a wild population from southeastern North America . Emotions can motivate social interactions and relationships and therefore are directly related with basic physiology , particularly with the stress systems . This is important because emotions are related to the perception of reality and thus directly related to the development of psychopathology : the perception of reality with a social dimension . Many studies show that psychopathology is related to the perception of the world , however , few studies show how this happens and what emotions influence this perception . For this reason , it is a question to examine if the experience of emotions during relationships and social interactions can impact health . 1 . Knowledge , for Popper , was objective , both in the sense that it is objectively true ( or truthlike ) , and also in the sense that knowledge has a priori truths , truths which could not be attained by empirical observation . These two notions are importantly different . The first , which was central to Popper 's thought , is that of the objective truth , of something , such as the set of human lives , that is , of an empirical datum . In science , we make hypotheses , and the only way to know whether the hypotheses are correct is to compare them against empirical data . This is knowledge : either it is correct , or it is not . The second notion is that of a priori truth , which in Popper is a truth like an empirical datum , a truth which we can establish before the data has been provided . This is where the difference lies . Both knowledge and a priori truth

Strict separation of powers did not operate in The United Kingdom , the political structure of which served in most instances [ citation needed ] as a model for the rest of the world through the American and British examples . Sep aration of powers is intended to protect against abuse because a single legislative body [ in this case ] can not be as flexible as it needs to be , such as changing the times and places of government meetings . The United States Constitution also creates an executive branch of government and a judiciary that are separate in structure , meaning that a single individual or body can not be given more power than is necessary for the performance of their duties . In the United Kingdom , both the legislative and executive authorities are not separate , only the judiciary is not separate from the legislative or executive . In order for this arrangement to work the authorities in the executive agency and the judiciary have to be independent and have separate procedures

Throughout the 14th century , French kings sought to expand their influence at the expense of the territorial holdings of the nobility . They ran into difficulties when attempting to rule their territories to suit their purposes . The population of the Middle Ages was small , and the French were far better soldiers than most of the other medieval European peoples . While France did not succeed in conquering and annexing other states in the early 14th century , France managed to control areas of its territory beyond its national boundaries , and to expand the boundaries of its holdings . France was a major power by 1416 , and a century later France was still expanding its boundaries in order to secure its frontier defenses in the French Wars . The French monarchy grew more powerful as well , and this resulted in increased unrest in France itself and in the Duchy of Brittany . Identity development is a stage in the adolescent life cycle . For most , the search for identity begins in the adolescent years . During these years , adolescents are searching for their own identity , trying to find out who they are . This process is very important . We all have a strong need to identify who we are in the world . Our identity is crucial for our survival and well being . It is the foundation and the driving force of our existence . We are human beings , who happen to be born into various social settings , with different roles in society . In essence , we are all born with a certain identity , with what kind of values we bring , how we live , speak , how we interact with people . If our identity is damaged , even partially , we will have various reactions and symptoms for a long time . This can range from , anger , depression , social withdrawal , stress , depression

Y DNA studies tend to imply a small number of founders in an old population whose members parted and followed different migration paths . In most Jewish populations , these initial founders were from neighboring and/or distant regions of the Diaspora . In addition , the lack of Y DNA studies in many other Arab-Jewish populations also may suggest a small number of founders . The relatively high number of founding groups and the small number of generations since their initial settlement probably account for many of the differences seen . One of the main goals of the Hebrew University study is to determine which genetic material from the founders in modern Israeli Jews can be transferred to the modern Jewish population using haplogroups commonly found among Ash kenazi Jews from North Africa . A second goal is to provide insight into past migrations of modern Ashkenazi Jews who intermarried with Jews of similar background who came from other parts of the globe , and compare these genetic data with the current YDNA samples

The deeper ancestral demography of Bermuda 's population has been obscured by the ethnic homogenisation of the last four centuries . There is effectively no ethnic distinction between black and white populations in Bermuda and this paper will , therefore , refer only to black and white Bermudians ( who represent almost half of the population ) . Bermuda has about two million residents and is a self -governed British Overseas Territory . In recent decades there has been a steady increase in the number of island residents who migrate from the mainland to the island . A significant minority of these immigrants make their home on both sides of the island ( and are the foundation for its racial , class and linguistic structures in the 21st century ) . The vast majority of residents live on the east and west banks and are connected to the local economy from the mainland , although in recent decades the economy has increasingly taken a more island - centered turn . Like the reptiles , birds are primarily uricotelic , that is , their kidneys extract nitrogenous waste from their bloodstream and excrete it as uric acid instead of urea or bicarbonate . The urea in birds is produced via the urine , and in reptiles , including lizards and turtles , it is produced via their guts . Most bird species urinate frequently , whereas reptiles , especially crocodiles , have the same urine output levels as humans . This has very important implications for their ability to cope with different climates , as they can only live in one place . The majority of reptiles are cold blooded , meaning that their body temperatures are not as high as those of mammals such as humans and can therefore endure colder temperatures but suffer from reduced heat loss . In contrast , the body temperature of mammals increases to prevent them from freezing . When Nintendo released the NES in the US , the design styling was deliberately different from that of other game consoles . Nintendo wanted to distinguish its product from those of Atari and Sega , and create a sense of a whole new game system to play . The designers had been experimenting with ideas for years on other products ( the Famicom and the SNES being the most prominent ) , but had no idea just how far they would go with the NES . After much experimentation over the course of many years , this was developed into a distinctive , highly-recogn izable design . The design of the NES was based on the Famicom design , but they improved upon it with a greater use of white , and a greater emphasis on the iconic `` Nintendo '' label on the back . Since the NES had many new ways to play with features like a microprocessor and more robust memory , the design team wanted to emphasize the differences from its competitors .

Many modern specialty matches have been devised , with unique winning conditions . The most common of these is the ladder match . In the basic ladder match , the players are ranked 1 to 6 and the order of the match is inverted for any one match . It is also called the top-rope match for the reason that the ladder is used to pull players off the opponent ` s shoulders . For example , the player below No . 4 starts on the ladder , the player below No . 5 has to get off the ladder before No . 4 ( or the player who sits in the 3rd highest rank ) does . There are many variations on the ladder match . In the common version of the ladder match , the players get to stand at ringside , and the ladder is used to pull the players ' shoulders up and away from the ring to get an advantage in the match . A true predator can commonly be known as one that kills and eats another living thing . Whereas other types of predator all harm their prey in some way , a true predator harms neither its victims nor its own prey . A true predator may do this by eating its prey , by killing it in order to eat its prey , or by infecting a member of its prey , which eventually kills it I . For a true predator no part of its prey is ever lost to it , which may be important for the survival of a true predator given its limited food supply . A true predator may occasionally eat prey it encounters , this is called opportunistic predation . It is most famous predators who do this : sharks and killer whales . Cuevas , Bernardo Couto , and Juan Bautista Almonte , was among the most important deals of the U.S . annexation . Pione ering work like Fe ynman 's led to the great advance in knowledge and engineering that led to modern computers . For example , while we know that all atoms , molecules and cells need electrons in order to survive , until Fe ynman the best we understood was that they needed just enough energy to do it , i.e . they needed enough for electron transfer . But how can you transfer an electron ? For that we needed something called a double barrier . Without electron transfer , there are no chemicals and no information . And without chemical and information systems , there would be no computers . And without computers

Some rock musicians today use mandolins , often single-stringed electric models rather than double-stringed acoustic mandolins . In his 2008 interview with the Associated Press Brennan told that he learned to play the mandolin , often called the f iddle of Irish music , when he was an 11- or 12-year- old in rural Ireland . The instrument 's origin lies , however , in the 16 th century in Italy . Mand olins were usually played by the male gentry and musicians . B orrowed from the Flemish aristocracy at the end of the renaissance , they were popular during the early medieval period , in Italy and the Balkans . The use of a double- stringed mandolin ( a double- baged mandolin ) made possible the development of a wide variety of styles in American music : jazz , Dixiel and , country blues . The final major aspect of identity formation is self-esteem . Self-esteem is defined as one 's thoughts and feelings about one 's self-concept and identity . Most theories on self-esteem highlight a number of characteristics of healthy self -esteem : The ability to experience oneself as competent as one 's mind and body abilities , a desire for constructive change , sense of well -being , and an interest in the self -related world . Self-esteem differs from psychological well -being in that it focuses on a person 's self -concept whereas psychological well -being focuses on a person ' s well being and self -esteem can be seen as a complementary concept to psychological well being . Self -esteem can be developed through positive external feedback or through internal feedback . Feedback is received by an individual in terms of a positive evaluation of oneself , whereas feedback is received by an individual in terms of negative views of oneself . The three states , and the subcontinent which they controlled , remained essentially under the domain of the Indo- European language and cultural communities . Early Modern universities initially continued the curriculum and research of the Middle Ages : natural philosophy , logic , medicine , theology , mathematics , astronomy ( and astrology ) , rhetoric and eloqu ence , law and politics , language and literature . In particular , German universities of the fifteenth and sixteenth centuries had already had a long tradition of teaching philosophy which preceded the advent of the formal division into natural science and `` humanistic '' disciplines . In their early stages , however , they taught natural philosophy and logic , astronomy as well as the liberal arts , mathematics , rhetoric , etc . This tradition came to a sudden end with the Renaissance and the emergence of the modern academy . The scientific temper had assumed a rigid character , and natural philosophy , though still being taught , was of a strictly positivist nature . The two major types of nonprofit organization are membership and board-only . A membership organization elects the board and has regular meetings and the power to amend the bylaws . This gives the group a lot of control over its operations . This differs from a board-only organization , where the board has an executive management authority over the organization but is not involved in the day- to-day operations . One advantage that board- only organizations have over membership organizations is that a membership organization must be able to show that it is in fact serving the public and is not only a private `` club `` or `` ass -ink-hole . `` A board -only organization must show that it is serving public interests . The law is different for each type of organization . An example of a private membership club would be the Chamber of Commerce , which represents private businesses . For example , menarche ( the first menstrual period of a woman ) and menarche onset are common markers of early adulthood . Similarly , pregnancy , birth and lactation are recognized by many as key developmental events . Yet , adolescence is a time full of tremendous changes in both physical and psychological development . Because adolescence is a time of rapid physical and emotional growth in humans and for many animals , developmental plasticity is a fundamental aspect of most models for postnatal brain and behavior development . For many adolescents psychological changes are significant ( e.g . , mood shifts , changes in sleep patterns , changes in interest and behavior ) that are the result of changes in the physiology and the environmental conditions of the teenage years . Changes in adolescence , thus , may be related to or different from the changes that occur when an infant enters the transitional stage

Although the doctrine of Mary 's Immaculate Conception appears only later among Latin ( and particularly Frankish ) theologians , it became ever more manifest among Byzantine theologians reliant on Jewish sources of religious guidance , by the beginning of the 13 th century . These included the Greek scholar Theophyl act , the Archbishop of Thessalon iki Gregory Palamas , and Patriarch Michael Cerularious , all Greek Orthodox Christians who stressed the importance of the doctrine . It was this third group of theologians - along with the Nestorian Chald ean monk Moses of Sinope and the Arabic Chald e an monk al B n an - who first proposed to the world that Mary was 'Immaculate Conception ' from the very beginning . From the 13 th century until the beginning of the 18 th century , the doctrine was often presented as representing the central message of Christianity as to how Mary could , and indeed must be regarded , despite being a woman and mortal , as the Mother of God .

Microbiological culture is a principal tool used to diagnose infectious disease . In a microbial culture , a growth medium is provided for a specific agent . A sample taken from a specimen taken from a patient is suspended in the medium as it is examined for an infectious agent . Hereinafter , a sample is usually referred to as a culturable isolate . The sample must be incubated under specific conditions . When the culture conditions are changed at any time during the culturing process , the result is a decrease in the amount of the cultured isolates . This phenomenon may affect quality and quantity of diagnostics . To avoid this problem , cultures should be treated for the formation of biofilms . 2 . The formation of bio films has been shown to be extremely slow for bacteria , whereas highly effective for a number of fungi and most viruses . 3 . It is , therefore , essential for microbial cultures to include a means for prevention of biofilm

While medieval pageants and festivals such as Corpus Christi were church-sanctioned , Carnival was also a manifestation of medieval folk culture . Many local Carnival customs are claimed to derive from Roman festivals , with Roman influence also being found in the Italian versions of the Spanish festival of San Juan . The traditional origin of the Carnival of Venice is still obscure , but many historians credit it to the Roman poet Hor atius Flacc us with the festival that became celebrated throughout all of Italy , and in many places also in Gaul , Germany , and Spain . In Venice , the date for the Feast of the M idsummer Saturnalia coincides with the anniversary of the fall of Pompeii on November 12 . It is unclear whether this festival and the later celebrations on June 23 were one and the same , but the early Roman festival of the Ides was celebrated by the Romans beginning , and it seems that the Roman Saturn alia of today has the same name .

These policies came under attack in 1989 , when protestors demanded an end to these socialist policies . Gaddafi responded by launching a full-scale military campaign to suppress the protestors . Mary 's complete sinlessness and concomitant exemption from any taint from the first moment of her existence was a doctrine familiar to Greek theologians of Byzantium . Beginning with St. Basil , a fourth century Greek , it was expounded many times in the Byzantine ecclesiastical tradition . The Eastern concept of Mary 's complete exemption from any taint of Adam 's Fall was not a new idea . It was the tradition as expounded , for example , by the Greek theologian John Chrysostom . In fact , Chrys ostom explicitly linked the virgin birth and Mary 's imm aculate conception with the doctrine of original sin and the doctrine of atonement . Chrysostom , a third century writer and preacher , used to say that she was free from sin ... as free as is possible for a creature to be . The initial military maneuvers began in September 1806 . In a notable letter to Marshal Soult detailing the plan for the campaign , Napoleon described the essential features of Napoleonic war on the European Peninsula . In particular , the initial stages of the war would be against the Austrian Empire and Britain . Once those enemies were dealt with , Napoleon urged , the French Army would enter Portugal . On a slightly larger scale than was planned , Napoleon 's ambitions in the West , however , would prove to be more ambitious still . French troops made a push into Portugal and Spain , but were stopped by the Spanish army under Marshal Victor . Boundaries can be inclusive or exclusive depending on how they are perceived by other people . An exclusive boundary arises , for example , when a person adopts a marker such as _the only _which delim its everyone other than that person . This is commonly thought of as marking a line that no person can jump over . The term inclusive occurs when multiple markers are used . An example of an inclusive boundary would be the concept of a family . An example of an exclusive boundary would be the concept of an ethnic group . To maintain a high constant body temperature is energy expensive – mammals therefore need a nutritious and plentiful diet . While the earliest mammals were probably predators , different species evolved different feeding habits , which are reflected in their anatom ies . Our lineage evolved into the vertebrates with a mouth adapted for the capture of food items . Other feeding methods are possible , like biting off chunks of food . The last major food groups to evolve were the insects , which the mammals captured by consuming living prey – so called preyed - ons . Other food groups evolved later : a variety of seed munch ing mammals and the herbivorous reptiles . The reptiles ate small , worm-like seeds and fruits ( see this page for more ) . Inverte brates are the main herbivores in South America and many of them are quite large . Most fatty acids are non-essential , meaning the body can produce them as needed , generally from other fatty acids and always by expending energy to do so . However , fatty acids are part of the basic structure of the cell membrane where their unique structure can bind to proteins , so that fatty acids can be used in this way . The fatty acids they bind to , however , often are necessary for normal , functioning of the cell . This is especially true of uns aturated fatty acids since they can not be broken down to their fatty acid constituents with which it has its fundamental chemical properties . Fat ty acids are also important from the physiological stand point of the body , which uses their biological properties such as the presence of unsaturation ( the number of unsaturated carbon atoms ) to identify them . In the wake of the Coventry Blitz , there was widespread agitation from the Communist Party over the need for bomb-proof shelters . Many Londoners , in particular , took to the roads on foot , leaving no one to man the stations . Thousands of people lined up , in the darkness , to watch trains pass overhead , as the authorities feared another attack . By the evening , several people had died , and there were fires across the city , not just at gas stations . Londoners , however , did not give up . They began to use the underground , which , it was hoped , would provide protection from the high- explosive devices that had failed so many times before . As night fell , the tunnels would no longer be suitable , but tunnels were dug on the outskirts . This , however , could only help people who lived in areas outside the city . Before the early 20th century , treatments for infections were based primarily on medicinal folklore . Mixtures with antimicrobial properties that were used in treatments of infections were described over a long time period by various cultures around the World . The first record of the use of a mixture as an antimicrobial appears in ancient Greek medical writings . It was also thought that many antimicrobial plant substances were used to treat infections , and it was believed that some of these plant substances , such as Artemisia , had a beneficial effect on patients . Artemisia was known to be able to prevent infections by interfering with the replication of viruses . However , with the passing of time , this was lost to the archaeological record . Other plant remedies used in ancient times , such as Moring a seeds , have been shown to have strong antimicrobial effects . In addition , there has been a suggestion that a mixture may be used to treat infections today , although it is not

A standard adult football match consists of two periods of 45 minutes each , known as halves . Each half runs continuously , meaning that the clock is not stopped while both teams are out of possession or at the end of a period . Teams score by kicking , drop-kicking or throwing the ball onto the goal line . The only goal-scoring method not covered by this is shooting at goal from any height with the ball . The match is won after three full periods . The first and second halves go at a time of 25 minutes , followed by a five-minute break for any additional time . If a penalty is awarded during the game , a replay is held for the next 15 minutes . The first official time for the match is the time the referee starts the first half , and the last official time is after the last goal is scored . This is usually around half-time . The referee decides when he wants the game halted

Communication within peer groups allows adolescents to explore their feelings and identity as well as develop and evaluate their social skills . Peer groups offer members the opportunity to develop a sense of social approval and acceptance within groups that are typically defined by shared values and culture . Peer group membership may also enhance physical and social safety . Staying in the peer group promotes social acceptance , personal responsibility , cooperation , and the development of communication skills . An adolescent 's peer group offers the adolescent , through the sharing of knowledge , experiences and ideals , the opportunity to develop their sense of identity , learn to identify with others and gain social skills . In the study , we wanted to explore two peer groups , defined as non- familial and familial , that differed on three different dimensions of the peer group : non-familial , personal , and relational . In 1681 , in partial repayment of a debt , Charles II of England granted William Penn a charter for what would become the Pennsylvania colony . Despite the royal charter , Penn did not own any land in Pennsylvania . The land had been acquired from several Native Americans before the Spanish- American War . Penn and his followers , the Quaker colonists , were granted certain rights in Maryland and the Pennsylvania colony . These included the freedom to meet together , the right to worship , as well as the right of dissent . This is how it worked - people with a stake in the charter - called Penns , could choose to belong to the colony 's ruling body , the General Assembly . Sleep does not affect acquisition or recall while one is awake . Therefore , sleep has the greatest effect on memory consolidation . During sleep , the neural connections in the brain are strengthened ( the synapses are more `` m ated '' ) and the areas that receive those memories are also being enhanced . At the same time memories are degraded , and the parts of brain for other tasks are shut down . This is the reason why people have the same memory when they wake up in the morning as when they went to sleep . Although sleep and dreaming is interesting , remember that we are only discussing how dreaming effects memory . Dreaming can be dangerous : it may wake you up in the middle of the night ! But it can also be an important time to study new things and form ideas about them . However , please do not confuse dreaming with day dreaming . Van Praag states that the Ming court established diplomatic delegations with Tibet merely to secure urgently needed horses . Wang and Nyima argue that these were not diplomatic delegations at all : rather they were horse traders who , in accordance with a Buddhist teaching , sought a peaceful resolution to the conflict . By making money from the sale of horses , Wang believed that Tibetan Buddhism would be strengthened . It is clear that Tibet was regarded from the Ming court as a resource . S ufficiently wealthy Tibet ans were expected to supply horses and other material for use by the court . This explains the large quantities of goods being imported from Tibet . However the relationship between the Ming court and Tibet has been seen as a case of the Ming court using Tibetans as an instrument to carry out its foreign policy . The independence of the Thirteen Colonies in North America in 1783 after the American War of Independence caused Britain to lose some of its oldest and most populous colonies . By the mid -18th century Britain had begun the process which led to the union of three English-speaking states for the first time since the 13th century . Over time , however , the union became increasingly weaker . In 1788 King George III created the American colonies as a territory under his personal control . In 1803 Napoleon defeated the British and ended British control of all the territory of western North America . The westernmost province , Upper Canada ( later renamed Canadian Federation ) was established in 18 67 . Upper Canada and the other eight United States became politically independent in 1867 by granting them the right to establish a Parliament . In 18 79 the American colonies were formally united after they had won the War of Independence of 1812 from Britain . American state boundaries were redrawn .

Different phases of digestion take place including : the cephalic phase , gastric phase , and intestinal phase . The cephalic phase occurs at the sight , thought and smell of food . It is followed by the gastric phase where the food material is first broken down by hydrolyzed proteins such as u reases , enzymes and peptides in the stomach and then sent to the dist al small intestine for absorption . The final phase of digestion , the intestinal phase , takes place in the duodenum ( small intestine ) and pyloric sp hincter . It is the place where foods are removed by bicarbon ate and enzymes and is followed by the formation of the final product . The small intestine also has a high concentration of hormones such as gastrin , progesterone , serotonin and gluc agon.The gast rital phase consists of the stomach lining and its tissues where food is absorbed and nutrients and energy are used . The number of species invasions has been on the rise at least since the beginning of the 1900s . Species are increasingly being moved by humans ( on purpose and unintentional ) and as a result , our species is losing a species every 60 seconds . Species diversity is diminishing globally . In the United Kingdom alone , there is a population loss of 100 million plants and animals every five years . The impact of climate change on the quality of the environment is a threat to biodiversity everywhere . Introduction of genetic engineering could become one of the major threats to the sustainability of our species - even beyond our time span . So far , however , it seems like human beings are not able to manage the introduction of genetically engineered organisms . Some people have been advocating the control of genetic engineering . Although gene editing is a complicated subject , one aspect of gene editing that is important is the need to ensure the efficiency of gene editing

In the spring of 1800 , Napoleon and his troops crossed the Swiss Alps into Italy , aiming to surprise the Austrian armies that had reoccupied the peninsula when Napoleon 's father , a French marshal , was killed in battle eight years earlier . The invasion was part of Napoleon 's grand design to `` liberate `` the peoples of European Europe from the yoke of the Hapsburgs ' . The invasion was a fiasco , but to the relief of Austria , it did draw off most of its armies from the border for a while , and the invasion was largely successful . In the end , the Emperor had very little to show for it . Napoleon was forced to give up his conquests in Italy and the rest of Europe . Austria was able to hold out for a further four-and -forty- one years as the French Empire collapsed and the Austrian monarchy was swept aside by the rising nationalism of the Hapsburgs and the Austrians . In 1877 , Thomas Edison invented the phonograph . Unlike the phonautograph , it was capable of both recording and reproducing sound . Despite the similarity of name , there are fundamental differences . A phon autograph ( or a phonautograph ) records the oral sounds of speech . The phonautograph records both the time and the relative position of the oral sounds on the tape . The combination of time and position on a tape is called recording time . Recording time of speech may be considered as recording the length of speech . In other words , the phonautograph records both time and position on the tape of speech . A phonograph records only the audio part of recorded speech and usually reproduces speech into words ( speech into word ) . However , phonography ( or phonography ) - recording of speech using a phonautograph only - is not possible , because no suitable material can be used to record sound wave . In biology , energy is an attribute of all biological systems from the biosphere to the smallest living organism . Within an organism it is responsible for growth and development . Energy is associated with life . Life is usually an active process of development , reproduction or maintenance . Energy is a common denominator . Energy can be represented , explained or explained . Energy is always life , and the simplest of energy is the photon . Photons are small particles . Photons can be thought of as particles for they are able to carry energy , and they can do this in many ways ( the energy carried by the photon can be a number of photons of different energies or a single photon ) . From 1877 to 1878 , the area suffered a rash of stagecoach robberies . Most notable , however , were the two holdups committed by masked road-agent William Whitney Brazelton and the mysterious John C. Moore . Brazelton held his customers at gun point and removed their money while the other masked robber , Moore , entered their car while they were on the way to dinner . The two men then made off with their victims ' belongings and car . On June 18 , 1877 , John Moore struck again - but this time he failed to abduct one wealthy passenger for whom he reserved special attention . Moore instead drove his victims to a nearby farm house where he raped and brutalized them . As Moore and his two accomplices fled north into the mountains with the stolen car , they were spotted when a passing mail carrier named E lisha Smith saw them in the woods and described their car to police . The works of Virgil almost from the moment of their publication revolutionized Latin poetry . The Eclogues , Georgics , and above all the Aeneid became standard texts in school . But Virgil 's masterpiece was his epic poem on the Trojan War , the Georgic poem Georg ics is usually classified as a didactic poem on a political and sociological issue : the question of a fair distribution of land and of the rights and responsibilities of the wealthy and well -connected . As such , it is at the centre of a wide literary debate . The question of distributive justice was important in the life of the poet at times of crisis such as those at which the Greek and Roman cities of his time were undergoing their wars . The poem is an exemplary document in literary history , its complex narrative style and poetic structure marking the beginning of a new literary genre that would dominate the rest of the literary history of Western culture : epic . The island of Saint Helena has a total area of 122 km2 ( 47 sq mi ) , and is composed largely of rugged terrain of volcanic origin ( the island is named after Saint Helena , the Roman name for the island ) . The island is a volcanic one , comprising several small , rocky out croppings of different heights and orientations , connected by narrow isthmal lines of basaltic lava , intersp ersed with lava flows and other intrusions . Saint Helena ( French : ) is in the Lesser Antilles , in the Atlantic Ocean , off the southern coast of South America and is the only island in the world within the Atlantic Ocean . The arch ipelago is the highest inhabited area on earth , with an altitude of 3 , 047 . The island lies within the equatorial region , and the average temperature is 25°C or 1 , 0 39 . On 1 September 1870 , the battle opened with the Army of Châlons , with 202 infantry battalions , 80 cavalry squadrons and 564 guns , attacking the surrounding Prussian positions . The French were supported by 2 cavalry brigades and a battalion of artillery . On the French side were two infantry brigades , 10 squadrons of cavalry and 72 artillery pieces . A number of other French units defended a line west and south of Orval and were withdrawn from support for a time . The Prussians had 4 cavalry brigades of 9 and 9 squadrons and 8 guns . In 1939 , the Bureau began compiling a custodial detention list with the names of those who would be taken into custody in the event of war with Axis nations . The list could include children and adults with disabilities , and was eventually made public . In 1990 , the list was amended to include those born in the 1940s , and the children and adults were given the legal status of `` prohibited immigrants ' . However , the list has not been updated since , and the immigration status of persons born in the 1940s is unknown as of August , 2001 . The original custodial detention list from 1939 is in the National Archives , RG 287 , PHS-13 -5 , in addition to the immigration records kept at the USCIS . The deliberate or accidental hybridising of two or more species of closely related animals through captive breeding is a human activity which has been in existence for millennia and has many known detrimental effects for animals , especially plants . The hybrid isation of several species is a consequence of human activities and can be used in order to increase genetic diversity within species and adapt their characteristics to human needs and to increase the yield of food and other products . The term can also be used to describe the deliberate acquisition by humans of animal species from other sources . The resulting hybrids are usually of lower genetic integrity compared to their parents , which reduces the chances of successful rearing and can result in diseases which the parents are unable to eliminate . These diseases result in both permanent and temporary damage to the animals , but the permanent damage is generally more noticeable as the gene pool becomes smaller . The success of its football team made Notre Dame a household name . The success of Note Dame reflected rising status of Irish Americans and Catholics in the 1920s . Football Team : From 1915 to 1915 the college had a football team . The team was disbanded at the end of the 1915 season . The men of the football team played as the school football team `` Paterno 's `` until 1917 . In that 1917 season of the school 's football team , the varsity included football players who were Notre Dame students or graduate students . From 1917 until the early 1950s , when it was disbanded entirely , its football team had only three seasons . In the 1915 , 1917 , and 1918 seasons , it had six winning seasons and two losing seasons . Those winning seasons were followed by its last losing one . In 1923 , it had won five games . Switzerland lies between latitudes 45° and 48° N , and longitudes 5° and 11° E. It contains three basic topographical areas : the Swiss Alps to the south , the Jura range to the north , and Lake Geneva , which lies to the west . Its name derived from the city of Verona in Italy ; it was later transferred to Geneva , Switzerland . At the end of the 19 th century , three areas of interest were discovered in Switzerland : the Eiffel Tower , Lake Geneva , and the Matter horn . As Muslim institutions of higher learning , the madrasa had the legal designation of waqf . In central and eastern Islamic lands , the view that the madrasa , as an asset of the state , was one which fell under the responsibility of the state meant that it was part of the wider state apparatus , and was subject to the state 's control . In other places , in both the Islamic and non-Islamic world , it had a broader meaning , that the madras a acted like a college , offering higher education . The state was responsible for regulating the madrasas , and the mad rasas were also given to regulate the actions of the various public agencies . Such regulatory control was in the nature of a state authority , and not a private authority , as had been the case with the shari ' a courts and su prastructure .
